results.content:
This course is really amazing value for money. Most courses that introduce a new technology involve building one (or a few) really trivial projects that bear no resemblance at all to any "real world" application that you would actually need to make. Not so with this course....

The project that you build might not be a complete real world application, but it is FAR from trivial, and involves so many things that you will need to do for real applications - just take a look at the Course Content! (or watch the intro videos, I guess)

Ironically, the course covers so much that at the end I feel kind of overwhelmed.... I look at some of the features we built, and I can't remember why or how things work sometimes. I will definitely need to watch sections of the course again to reinforce concepts. The good news, of course, is that the videos DO cover these things, and I'm not left scratching my head and wishing that the course had covered how to do X. 

Neil is very good at explaining what he is doing, and he usually answers questions very quickly (unlike some courses I've done).

Oh.... it should be noted that this is an intermediate level course, really. If you are completely new to programming or web development, this is a course you need to wishlist, and come back to after you've done other introductory courses.

results.content: Neil's course covers a lot of ground and gives you a first hand look at how a professional web app is built. In terms of scope and features, no other course I've taken on this platform comes close. While not everything is explained in excruciating detail, Neil does a fine job covering the theoretical basics and being responsive when you're trying to understand things deeper. If you're interested in the React/Redux/Firebase stack then this course is a no-brainer as you'll walk away with tons of applicable knowledge that you can use for your own projects.

results.content: By far the best React course on Udemy, too bad it is not rated higher. Very hands-on approach, Neil covers most common features of a real-world application. I have tried other more popular courses, but for a beginner like me, they bog you down with so much theory, setups, testings and details that, while useful and necessary, leave you lost and intimidated but how much is necessary to learn. I suggest that you take this course first, so you get a sense of how all pieces fit together while building something actually useful. After this, you can and should take other courses that cover testing, deployment, connecting to APIs, etc. I wouldn't add or remove anything from this course, too much and it would be overwhelming; too little and it would be ineffective. Very organized and perfect pace. Thank you Neil!

results.content: The best aspect of the course is the way Neil purposely takes you through several iterations of development, starting with a React-only implementation, then refactoring the code base each time to show you how Redux, Redux Form, and other tools and libraries affect the previous version. It gave me a better understanding of when, where, and why to use the more advanced approaches. My impression is that the final product is built in a style that you would expect to see on a sophisticated project. There are a few places where it would have been helpful to have had a little more explanation about what some of the more sophisticated functions were doing under the hood (e.g. how Redux Form was using Semantic UI components to create higher order components and what things to keep in mind if you opted to go that route), but I would rather be exposed to the pattern than skip it for the sake of keeping it simple.  Overall - a superb course.

results.content:
I rate 3.5 stars for the course and have a few reviews with this course:
- First you need to remember: This course is not for newbies to React. because Neil seldom goes into theory and only gives a very brief introduction ... but it also saves a lot of time for people who are already familiar with React.

- Good point: If you are familiar with React and you want to make a really big project, have many cool features, become familiar with firebase, firestore and do not want to spend a lot of time to care about the CSS of the project then This is the course for you. I have learned two React courses on Udemy, this is the third one and Neil's project is the largest and has the most features compared to the rest React courses.

- Good point: Neil supports everyone in QA very quickly, this is the difference from the rest of Udemy.

- The bad thing about this course is that the features of the firebase provided Neil with a very brief introduction, making me sometimes not really understand what it really is, not understanding what he's really doing,
It would be a lot better if Neil explained the firebase features he was about to introduce.

- The next bad point is that the course has not introduced much about Hook in React, this is a very important feature that any course must go into depth to spend it, but Neil is very short introduction . Honestly, I'm quite disappointed.

Update: 
The project is experiencing an extremely serious error, but the author has no response in the QA section

results.content:
BEFORE YOU TAKE THIS COURSE you should know that it is about 2 years old and there are some major dependency issues. DO NOT copy and paste Neil's package.json file and run the 'npm install' commmand as instructed in the beginning of the course. This will break everything and make you miserable. Instead, start only with the packages you need and as you go throughout the course add new packages/dependencies whenever Neil introduces them, making sure to use the EXACT VERSION that Neil does.

Despite all the pain and frustration I needlessly suffered throughout this course, I am still giving it a 5 star rating because of how invaluable a lot of this knowledge is. As a self-taught developer, trying to quickly build web applications for freelance clients, Firebase takes the hassle out of backend development and lets you quickly and easily build great web apps, like the one shown in this course.

I would have taken me many, many weeks to figure all this out on my own, but Neil did a good job at putting a bunch of pieces together in an easy-to-understand way. I have learned a lot throughout this course and would recommend it to anyone considering using Firebase in their web applications.

A Few Criticisms:
-I wish Neil explained React and Redux in more detail, or explicitly state in the intro that this was not an intensive course on React and Redux itself but more on how to use those libraries with Firebase to make web applications. This course was my first introduction to React and Redux and I found it insufficient to really understand how these libraries work. I had to supplement this course with Tyler McGinnis's courses on React and Redux to really understand what was going on in the earlier sections.
-I wish Neil didn't use so many dependencies. Nowadays, using the newer versions of React and Firebase, you could redo this course with a small fraction of all the dependencies used by Neil. I felt that while using another dependency or package was convenient and quick, it really stunted my learning as I often had no idea what was going on in the libraries we were using. I think a lot of them were unnecessary, and though it would have made the course longer, Neil could have shown us how to build the app using more React and Redux, rather than a bunch of React and Redux packages. Using less dependencies would have also resulted in less dependency issues, now that the course has aged and multiple dependencies used in it have had code-breaking updates in their newest versions.

I really enjoyed the 2nd half of the course which is why I've rated it so highly despite my critiques. Thank you Neil for all the time and effort you've invested in the course. We students are incredibly grateful!

results.content:
Edit from july 2020 update:
Ok... this course is now AMAZING! Honestly. I learn a lot of new stuff through those online learning websites and quite frankly, this course nails down everything you need to become a react developer. I liked the old course, but as stated, it was a little deprecated. I had a hard time installing those outdated libraries and trying to finish the course, but it was doable. The lack of React Hooks in the old course was a big let down... but NOW! This course has it all... If you struggled understanding Redux with other courses, well, try this. Neil has a way of teaching things and I really enjoy his style. I've bought many courses from the author and he is probably one of the most talented teacher out there (see, I didn't say the most talented developer, but when it comes to learning, I think what you need is someone who can teach effectively, not an amazing over engineering developer, which Neil is not).

I am very satisfied with this course so far, I am over 10h in, after doing almost 40h of the old content. I am still learning new things. I thikn the author listened and there is a lot more manual typing, which I consider essential to the learning process. Snippets are good for fast, ephemeral learning. Again, thumbs up for this, I went from 4.5 stars to 5 stars on this update. Good job to the author. Keep up the good work (original review below)

Original Review:
I expected more manual typing! I know, it is tedious, but I've followed many of your other courses where we type everything manually, and I really like it. It makes you feel how it would be like to type all those things and it makes you learn by doing it. I am a bit disapointed that we get to have all baked up code at that point, but Udemy asked me after the first half of section 3, so I hope there's gonna be more typing in the rest of the course. Again, very good course, well detailed, the instructor knows what he's talking about, I really like his style. Everything is so clear, we are not faced with some weird things that needs to be explained, but the instructor says that it's too complicated and we don't need to know about it. Keep up the good work!

results.content: If you are reading these comments before deciding to buy this course, the answer is yes, 100% do so- no really, just do it I promise your won't regret it. I have done another higher rated course on react + redux previously which setup the basics, but as soon as I tried to make my own stuff I felt frustrated with being unable to problem solve and implement other features. Neil's course is ridiculously complete and feature rich to the extent that I can't really think of other features for any other apps I would realistically need for quite some time. This course feels as if the author was hired to create a full complete polished app with bells and whistles on, and you are lucky enough to get mentored along the way. He doesn't leave anything out, and moreover polishes the finer details on the various features like a madman, these "little things" seem relatively insignificant at first glance, but then when you see how much work is actually required for these things to be implemented you realise how much time you have just been saved by this conscientious person. Now that I have gone through the course, my dream of becoming a real developer in the next couple of years seems so much closer to a reality, probably saved myself a year at least. Cheers Neil!

results.content:
The course material was fantastic.  I am an old-hat Java coder with minor experience in Javascript (think - HTML 2.0).  This gave me the knowledge I need to begin a whole new app in React/Redux/Firebase.

One recommendation: create some simple flow diagrams outlining the data flows between components, props, state, reducer, action, action creators, etc.

Maybe walk through a super-simple example of EventList passing props to EventDetail, clicking the "JOIN" button, how that information/action flows back to state, etc.

A single slide, a few boxes and arrows, a bit of animation/build-out with dialog describing it all.  Would be excessively helpful.  Code walkthroughs are hard for new folks to absorb because we're trying to build the mental model (the diagrams) while listening to new concepts being introduced and code being journeyed through.

results.content:
Probably the most thorough and advanced class I've taken. You ned up with a pretty impeccable and sophisticated application at the end which is what you need to understand things like application file architecture and just generally more advanced concepts like could functions and database storage and retrieval. 

I have taken simpler courses before on React so I knew what to expect. This class gave me a production-ready application utilizing the next generation of server technologies with Google Firebase. A lot of an application isn't just building one big feature, it's the small things like setting up accounts, and the micro-experience that a user expects and this course covers those small details so that a user can come in and expect this to be a professional polished applicaiton. 

These are the types of tutorials that get me excited for application development and will be a blueprint for business projects and my own personal projects!

results.content:
Installing Node Version Manager was a bit dodgy.  Spend the time to keep a step by step PDF by OS that keeps current.  Limit the options or do not even have choice for NVM since that is not the primary goal of this course.

Second, I installed NVM and install Node.js latest versions and installed the stable version via download from the site the stable version.  https://nodejs.org/en/

Only through trial and error did I realize if you don't install via Powershell NVM command, NVM will not recongize the Windows 10 download and install.

Also, I know perhaps some programmers feel they have more control with keyboard shortcuts, Terminal and Command Prompts but seriously, Windows, Menu, Drop Down should be incorporated.  It is the 21st century and I feel like we're still working not that far above punch cards.
results.content_html:

Also, I know perhaps some programmers feel they have more control with keyboard shortcuts, Terminal and Command Prompts but seriously, Windows, Menu, Drop Down should be incorporated. It is the 21st century and I feel like we're still working not that far above punch cards.

results.content:
I have taken probably over 100 courses on Udemy, and Neil's course on React and Firestore is easily among the top three. Here's why:

* Neil is very well organized, and he explains everything in a clear and concise manner.

* In the course, you will create an entire web app, one that is truly professional. Indeed, it is the best work product I've ever had come out of a Udemy course.

* You will learn best practices from Neil, who is clearly an extremely professional and experienced developer.

* Neil goes out of his way to anticipate problems students will have while following along; additionally, he always anticipates edge cases and accounts for them.

* The overwhelming focus of the course is building a real-world app. Theory is introduced where necessary.

In sum, if you know JavaScript, and have a bit of React knowledge, you will benefit immensely from taking this course. Beginners at React will develop their skills more than they could imagine. Even intermediate-to-expert React developers could take away a lot from this course. I don't know what else to say besides: BUY THIS COURSE. You will not regret it.
